sentence_1: Hector Macdonald Laws (Hec) Waller, DSO & Bar (4 April 1900 – 1 March 1942) was a senior officer in the Royal Australian Navy (RAN).
sentence_2: His career spanned almost thirty years, including service in both world wars.

sentence_1: At the helm of HMAS Stuart in the Mediterranean from 1939 to 1941, he won recognition as a skilful ship's captain and flotilla commander.
sentence_2: He then transferred to the South West Pacific as captain of the light cruiser HMAS Perth, and went down with his ship against heavy odds during the Battle of Sunda Strait in early 1942.Born in Benalla, Victoria, Waller entered the Royal Australian Naval College at the age of thirteen.

sentence_1: After graduating, he served with the Royal Navy in the closing stages of World War I.
sentence_2: Between the wars, he specialised in communications and was posted as signals officer to several British and Australian warships.

sentence_1: He gained his first seagoing command in 1937, as captain of the destroyer HMS Brazen.
sentence_2: In September 1939, he took charge of HMAS Stuart and four other obsolete destroyers that together became known as the "Scrap Iron Flotilla".

sentence_1: In 1940, these were augmented by other ships to form the 10th Destroyer Flotilla, supporting Allied troops in North Africa.Waller was awarded the Distinguished Service Order and Bar, and twice mentioned in despatches, for his achievements in the Mediterranean.
sentence_2: He assumed command of HMAS Perth in October 1941, taking part in the Battle of the Java Sea shortly before his final action in Sunda Strait.

sentence_1: He received a third mention in despatches posthumously, and in 2011 came under formal consideration for the award of the Victoria Cross for his performance as Perth's captain.
sentence_2: The submarine HMAS Waller is named in his honour.Born on 4 April 1900 in Benalla, Victoria, Hector MacDonald Laws Waller was the son of William Frederick Waller, a grocer, and his wife Helen Waller (née Duncan).Waller entered the Royal Australian Naval College (RANC) as a cadet midshipman on 31 December 1913, aged thirteen.

sentence_1: Promoted to midshipman on 1 January 1918, he was posted to Britain where, in April, he was appointed to serve in the Royal Navy's (RN) Grand Fleet with the dreadnought HMS Agincourt.In February 1919, Waller was assigned to the light cruiser HMAS Melbourne, and two months later returned to Australia.By this stage of his career, Waller had acquired a strong reputation for his communications work.
sentence_2: In July 1930, he was posted aboard the Royal Australian Navy's (RAN) flagship, the heavy cruiser HMAS Australia, as squadron signals officer.At the outbreak of World War II, Waller was appointed captain of HMAS Stuart, taking charge of a group of four other obsolete ex-RN destroyers—HMA Ships Vampire, Vendetta, Voyager, and Waterhen—that the Germans later nicknamed the "Scrap Iron Flotilla".Following Italy's entry into the war on 10 June 1940, Waller was involved in the search for minefields off the North African coast.

sentence_1: A keen shooter, he personally blew up floating mines using a rifle and armour-piercing bullets.
sentence_2: On 21 June, Stuart shelled the Italian-held town of Bardia.

sentence_1: In September, he was awarded the Distinguished Service Order (DSO) for "courage, enterprise, and devotion to duty on recent engagements"—in particular, his pinpointing of enemy minefields.—Crewman quoted by historian Tom LewisStuart and other ships of Waller's 10th Destroyer Flotilla supported the assaults on Tobruk in January 1941 and Benghazi the following month.Waller earned the personal admiration of Admiral Cunningham, who described him as "one of the finest types of Australian naval officers ... greatly loved and admired by everyone".Departing the Mediterranean, Waller returned to Australia in August 1941 for service in the South West Pacific.
sentence_2: In January 1942, the ship was assigned to American-British-Dutch-Australian Command (ABDA) to help defend the Dutch East Indies.

sentence_1: She set sail for the ABDA Area on 15 February, the day that Singapore surrendered.The ABDA Striking Force that Perth had joined was crushed by an overwhelming Japanese force at the Battle of the Java Sea on 27 February.
sentence_2: Low on ammunition, Waller made the decision to withdraw, accompanied by the cruiser USS Houston under the command of Captain Albert H. Rooks.

sentence_1: Waller's action contravened the orders of his Dutch superior, Admiral Conrad Helfrich, to "continue action whatever the cost, and till the bitter end", but the Australian was convinced that further engagement would mean pointless sacrifice.On the following night, 28 February, Perth and Houston were attempting to break through the Sunda Strait to Australia when they encountered a Japanese invasion fleet escorted by four cruisers and twelve destroyers.On 15 March 1946, Waller was awarded a posthumous mention in despatches for "gallantry and resolution" aboard HMAS Perth.Hec Waller's name appears on the Roll of Honour located at Panel 6 in the Commemorative Area at the Australian War Memorial, Canberra, and on the Plymouth Naval Memorial in Devon, England.HMAS Waller, the third of the RAN's Collins-class submarines to enter service, was commissioned on 10 July 1999.
sentence_2: The attendees included John Waller, Michael Waller's wife, and surviving crewmen of HMAS Perth.

sentence_1: US Highway 23 (US 23)  is a north–south United States Numbered Highway that runs from Jacksonville, Florida, to Mackinaw City, Michigan.
sentence_2: In the US state of Michigan, it is a major, 362-mile-long (583 km), north–south state trunkline highway that runs through the Lower Peninsula.

sentence_1: The trunkline is a freeway from the Michigan–Ohio state line near Lambertville to the city of Standish, and it follows the Lake Huron shoreline from there to its northern terminus.
sentence_2: Serving the cities of Ann Arbor and Flint, US 23 acts as a freeway bypass of the Metro Detroit area.

sentence_1: Overall, the highway runs through rural areas of the state dominated by farm fields or woodlands; some segments are urban in character in the Ann Arbor, Flint and Tri-Cities areas.
sentence_2: The section from Flint north to Standish also carries Interstate 75 (I-75) along a concurrency that includes a segment that carries almost 70,000 vehicles on a daily basis.The first transportation routes along what is now US 23 in the state were sections of two Indian trails.

sentence_1: The route of what is now US 23 follows portions of two separate trails.
sentence_2: In the early 20th century, four different auto trail names were applied to roads now a part of the highway.

sentence_1: These roads were included as part of two state highways in the initial state highway system in 1919.
sentence_2: When the United States Numbered Highway System was first designated on November 11, 1926, the new US 23 replaced the other designations along its route.

sentence_1: Since creation, the road has been moved and realigned several times.
sentence_2: Through the 1930s and 1940s, the lakeshore routing was created to replace a path that ran further inland through the northern portion of the state.

sentence_1: Starting in the early 1950s, various sections in the southeastern and central areas of the Lower Peninsula were upgraded to freeways, bypassing several major cities in the area.
sentence_2: These improvements were completed by the end of the 1960s.

sentence_1: Since then a new crossing of the Saginaw River at Zilwaukee was built to replace a drawbridge that carried the I-75/US 23 freeway over a shipping channel.Various memorial or tourist route designations have been applied to US 23 in the state since the 1980s.
sentence_2: The highway has been a part of the Lake Huron Circle Tour since the creation of the Great Lakes Circle Tours in 1986.

sentence_1: The non-freeway section was designated the Sunrise Side Coastal Highway by the Michigan Department of Transportation (MDOT) in 2004 as a part of what is now the Pure Michigan Byway Program.
sentence_2: Since 2009, it has been called the Huron Shores Heritage Route.

sentence_1: The highway has also carried two memorial designations related to war veterans and a third related to local civic leaders since a 2001 consolidation of related legislation in the state.
sentence_2: MDOT has listed two of the highway's bridges on its historic bridge list, one of which is also on the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP).

sentence_1: Future improvements to the route of US 23 include a proposed northerly extension of the freeway from Standish to one of several locations along the Lake Huron shoreline.
sentence_2: Another freeway has been proposed in the Flint area that could connect US 23 directly to the south end of I-475.US 23 runs for 362.152 miles (582.827 km) through the Lower Peninsula of Michigan, serving as a freeway bypass to the west of Metro Detroit and a scenic highway  through the northern portion of the state along Lake Huron.

sentence_1: Between Flint and Standish, US 23 runs concurrently with I-75; Like other state trunkline highways, it is maintained by the Michigan Department of Transportation (MDOT).
sentence_2: All of US 23 in the state south of the M-32 junction in Alpena has been listed on the National Highway System,US 23 enters Michigan on a freeway northwest of Toledo, Ohio, concurrent with US 223.

sentence_1: This freeway runs north through farm fields in rural western Monroe County near Lambertville.
sentence_2: About five miles (8.0 km) north of the state line, US 223 leaves the freeway and turns west onto St. Anthony Road; US 23 continues northward on the freeway.

sentence_1: South of Dundee, US 23 crosses the River Raisin before coming to an interchange with M-50 next to the Cabela's store west of town.
sentence_2: North of town, the freeway passes near an industrial area.The landscape takes on a more suburban residential character as the freeway approaches the Ann Arbor area.

sentence_1: There are separate interchanges for US 12 (Michigan Avenue) and I-94 on the southeast side of the city.
sentence_2: Between I-94 and Washtenaw Avenue, US 23 carries the Business Loop I-94 (BL I-94) moniker as well.

sentence_1: That secondary designation leaves the freeway and runs west on Washtenaw Avenue into downtown Ann Arbor and the campus of the University of Michigan.
sentence_2: At the same interchange, a Business US 23 (Bus.

sentence_1: US 23) designation also follows Washtenaw Avenue to the west; east of US 23, M-17 follows Washtenaw Avenue and connects the freeway with Ypsilanti.
sentence_2: North of this interchange, US 23 crosses the Huron River near the campus of the local community college and continues north to a junction with the M-14 freeway.

sentence_1: The two merge and run westward along the north side of the city before US 23 turns north and M-14 curves south.North of Ann Arbor, the freeway runs through woodlands and near several lakes.
sentence_2: In the community of Whitmore Lake, US 23 crosses into Livingston County near the city's namesake body of water.

sentence_1: East of Brighton, the freeway intersects I-96 and continues north to an intersection with M-59 south of Hartland.
sentence_2: The highway turns northeasterly by Runyon Lake and runs toward the city of Fenton.

sentence_1: The trunkline passes through town and bends back toward the northwest, running between lakes Ponemah and Fenton.
sentence_2: Continuing north, the environment around US 23 transitions to rural farm fields as the freeway approaches the south side of the Flint area.West of Grand Blanc, US 23 meets I-75, and the two freeways merge near the Bishop International Airport and continue along the west side of the Flint metro area.

sentence_1: These traffic counts are expressed in terms of annual average daily traffic (AADT), which is a statistical calculation of the average daily number of vehicles on a segment of roadway.Near Birch Run, the highway turns northwesterly next to a large outlet mall.
sentence_2: Between here and the Saginaw area, the freeway runs through more wooded lands, crossing the Cass River near Bridgeport.

sentence_1: I-75/US 23 enters the Tri-Cities (named for Saginaw, Bay City and Midland) when it bypasses Saginaw to the east.
sentence_2: The freeway intersects M-46 in Buena Vista Township south of the junction with I-675.

sentence_1: North of downtown Saginaw, the freeway crosses the Saginaw River on the Zilwaukee Bridge,Past the bridge, I-75/US 23 meets the northern end of I-675 and continues through fields and woods to the Bay City area.
sentence_2: At exit 162, the freeway meets the eastern terminus of US 10 and the western terminus of M-25 west of downtown.

sentence_1: The next interchange north is with the Connector M-13 (CONN M-13) freeway, which was the previous northern end of US 23's freeway in Michigan.
sentence_2: The connector runs due northward, and I-75/US 23 turns northwesterly to bypass around Kawkawlin.

sentence_1: The highway veers north, crosses the Kawkawlin River and the Pinconning Creek before coming to an interchange southwest of Standish.
sentence_2: There, US 23 curves east, separating from I-75.

sentence_1: US 23 continues for about three miles (4.8 km) as a freeway which ends at the intersection with M-13 south of Standish.US 23 runs north from the end of its freeway along Huron Road through the community of Standish.
sentence_2: The trunkline turns northeasterly  through lakeshore woodlands after the intersection with Old M-76.Oscoda is the location of the eastern termini of both the River Road National Scenic Byway and County Road F-41.

sentence_1: In between those two junctions, the highway crosses the Au Sable River near its mouth, and the trunkline passes by the former Wurtsmith Air Force Base.
sentence_2: Huron Road continues north, running next to Van Etten Lake as it leaves the national forest.

sentence_1: Further north, it runs along Cedar Lake when it crosses into Alcona County.When US 23 enters Alpena, it follows State Street through town and turns northwesterly on Chisholm Street.
sentence_2: The intersection of Chisholm and Washington streets marks the eastern terminus of M-32.

sentence_1: Chisholm Street runs along the Thunder Bay River and crosses the river near Lake Besser.
sentence_2: The highway leaves town and runs through rural woodlands to the south shore of Long Lake, curving around the eastern side of the lake.

sentence_1: Near the northern end of the lake, US 23 crosses into Presque Isle County and runs along the west shore of Grand Lake.
sentence_2: At the north end of that lake, the highway turns west along the Lake Huron shoreline near Thompson's Harbor State Park.

sentence_1: The trunkline continues to Rogers City where it bypasses town to the south and west, intersecting F-21 and M-68 in the process; Bus.
sentence_2: US 23 runs through downtown.

sentence_1: On the other side of Rogers City, US 23 runs along the lake past Hoeft State Park and along Hammond Bay before crossing into Cheboygan County.US 23 follows the Lake Huron shoreline through Cheboygan County through woodlands past Cheboygan State Park and Duncan Bay.
sentence_2: On the eastern edge of Cheboygan the highway intersects F-05 before following State Street through a commercial district.

sentence_1: State Street crosses the Cheboygan River on the Cheboygan Bascule Bridge near the mouth of the river and the dock for the USCGC Mackinaw.
sentence_2: On the west side of the river, US 23 meets the northern terminus of M-27 at the intersection with Main Street.

sentence_1: State Street continues westerly as C-66 as US 23 turns north on Main Street for a block before resuming west on Mackinaw Avenue.
sentence_2: The highway continues along the lake toward Mackinaw City.

sentence_1: As it approaches the village, it passes Historic Mill Creek State Park and several motels.
sentence_2: At Nicolet Street in town, the highway crosses into Emmet County for the short distance to the highway's national northern terminus at I-75's exit 338.Before Michigan became a state, the first land transportation corridors were the Indian trails.Later, during the auto trail era, the modern US 23 also coincided with the east branch of the Dixie Highway and part of the Lower Peninsula section of the Theodore Roosevelt International Highway.

sentence_1: The Dixie Highway was created by William S. Gilbreath after he developed the Lincoln Highway.
sentence_2: The highway was designed to link the Great Lakes with the Gulf of Mexico, and to commemorate a half century of peace between the North and the South after the American Civil War.

sentence_1: At the urging of Governor Woodbridge Ferris, the northern terminus was located at the Straits of Mackinac.
sentence_2: The highway had two branches in the Lower Peninsula; the eastern branch followed what later became US 23 north of Standish.The highway was also part of the East Michigan Pike, designed to be a counterpart of the West Michigan Pike on the other side of the Lower Peninsula.

sentence_1: The original route of the East Michigan Pike included a section along the coast of The Thumb between Bay City and Port Huron and used the same route as the Dixie Highway north of Bay City.
sentence_2: Backers of this auto trail lost out in terms of name recognition to the Dixie Highway, relegating the East Michigan Pike to the list of failed auto trails.

sentence_1: The southern part of what is now US 23 in the state was also part of the auto trail craze.
sentence_2: The Top of Michigan Trail was designated in 1917 from the state line north to the Bay City area, before turning inland along other roadways.

sentence_1: The name faded from shortly after the time the Michigan State Highway Department (MSHD)The first state highways along the US 23 corridor were numbered M-65 from the Ohio line north to the Flint area and M-10 from Flint north to Mackinaw City by July 1, 1919.US 23 was commissioned on November 11, 1926, with the debut of the United States Numbered Highway System.Starting in 1929, MSHD started updating the route that US 23 followed through the Lower Peninsula.
sentence_2: Late that year, the routing was moved to the east side of the Saginaw River, and M-47 was extended along the former course on the west side of the river.In 1932, US 23 was moved closer to the lakeshore between Spruce and Alpena; the former routing was redesignated M-171.US 23 was moved to its current lakeshore routing between Rogers City and Cheboygan in 1940, and M-33 was extended westerly from Onaway to Afton and north to Cheboygan over the former US 23 roadway while M-68 was extended eastward through Onaway to Rogers City.One of the first pieces of what would later become part of US 23's freeway route was completed in late 1951 or early 1952, when a two-lane bypass was built around the eastern side of Milan.The first future freeway portion of US 23 was built in 1957 from north of Ann Arbor to Whitmore Lake as a divided highway.In late 1960 or early 1961, a new I-75/US 10/US 23 freeway was built from the north end of the Saginaw bypass to Kawkawlin, utilizing the Zilwaukee drawbridge (later replaced by the Zilwaukee Bridge) over the Saginaw River; when it opened, MSHD extended M-13 along the former route of US 23 from the northside of Saginaw into Bay City to the end of the freeway at Kawkawlin.

sentence_1: Another section connected the Whitmore Lake area with Brighton in the same timeframe.The MSHD requested additional Interstate Highway mileage in 1968 under the Federal-Aid Highway Act of 1968 including a freeway along US 23 between Standish and Mackinaw City.The MSHD first proposed a realignment of US 223 in 1965; this change would reroute that highway to replace M-151 in southern Monroe County, and use the US 23 freeway to connect to Sylvania, Ohio.The original bridge across the Saginaw River at Zilwaukee was built in 1960 as a bascule bridge to allow shipping traffic to use the river.
sentence_2: Opening the drawbridge would back traffic up on I-75/US 10/US 23 for upwards of four hours on holiday weekends.

sentence_1: Approved in 1974, construction on the replacement bridge started in October 1979.
sentence_2: A major construction accident in August 1982 delayed completion of the new Zilwaukee Bridge; a bridge pier partially collapsed when contractors overloaded a section under construction.

sentence_1: The affected 300-foot (91 m) deck segment tilted to rest three feet (0.91 m) higher on one end and five feet (1.5 m) lower on the other.)
sentence_2: when the southbound span finally opened on September 19, 1988.While that construction was being done, MDOT truncated US 10 at Bay City in 1986; this removed the concurrency between US 10 and US 23 that existed since 1926.In November 2016, construction work began on the freeway between Ann Arbor and Whitmore Lake.

sentence_1: This construction includes replacement of bridges and reconstruction of off ramps.Officials in the Flint area have proposed extending a freeway to directly connect  I-475 to US 23.
sentence_2: Such an extension, if built, would "include a new freeway coming out of I-475, which would snake across Fenton and Cook roads before connecting into US 23 at Baldwin Road".Most of US 23, along with US 2 in the Upper Peninsula, has been designated the United Spanish War Veterans Memorial Highway.

sentence_1: The designation was conferred in Public Act 207 of 1945, with companion legislation for US 2 in 1949.
sentence_2: Signs marking the highway were not erected until 1968 when Governor George W. Romney had them installed.North of Standish, US 23 is a part of the Lake Huron Circle Tour (LHCT).When the Michigan State Legislature consolidated the statutes defining the various memorial highways in 2001, they included the Veterans of World War I Memorial Highway in the law.

sentence_1: Defined along I-75/US 23 between Saginaw and Bay City, the designation was included in Public Act 142.
sentence_2: That act also affected another previously designated moniker between the two cities.

sentence_1: The Roberts-Linton Highway was named in 1931 for local leaders who championed the construction of a highway along the Saginaw River.
sentence_2: This name was applied to the original highway routing between Saginaw and Bay City (now a part of M-13).

sentence_1: After the 2001 change, the name was moved to the US 23 freeway.In May 2004, the highway north of Standish was named the Sunrise Side Coastal Highway, a scenic highway designation through what is now called the Pure Michigan Byway Program.
sentence_2: At the end of 2011, the Northeast Michigan Council of Governments (NEMCOG) was working on funding a tourist promotion called "Telling Stories of the Sunrise Coast" through the US 23 Heritage Route Interpretive Program.

sentence_1: Past efforts by NEMCOG included print media, logos, and other marketing efforts.MDOT maintains a listing of the historic bridges in the state; along US 23, the department has listed two structures.
sentence_2: The bridge over the Ocqueoc River in Ocqueoc Township in Presque Isle County was built in 1937.

sentence_1: The 106-foot-long (32 m) structure is one of the last three deck truss bridges in the state.
sentence_2: The roadway on the bridge is 38 feet (11.6 m) wide and carries two lanes of traffic.

sentence_1: The bridge was reconstructed in 1994.The second bridge is the Cheboygan Bascule Bridge in Cheboygan.
sentence_2: This bascule bridge was built in 1940 over the Cheboygan River as the last of its kind before World War II.

sentence_1: It was built as a "two-leaf bridge in a place where a single-leaf bridge probably would have sufficed."
sentence_2: The structure is 155 feet (47 m) long, composed of two 42-foot (13 m) spans on either side of the central 70-foot (21 m) span; the roadway is 40 feet (12 m) wide with four lanes for vehicle traffic.

sentence_1: There are also pedestrian sidewalks on either side of the roadway.
sentence_2: When the bridge is opened to allow river traffic to pass, boats have a 60-foot-wide (18 m) channel for navigation.Route map:

sentence_1: Homeworld is a real-time strategy video game developed by Relic Entertainment and published by Sierra Studios on September 28, 1999, for Microsoft Windows.
sentence_2: Set in space, the science fiction game follows the Kushan exiles of the planet Kharak after their home planet is destroyed by the Taiidan Empire in retaliation for developing hyperspace jump technology.

sentence_1: The survivors journey with their spacecraft-constructing mothership to reclaim their ancient homeworld of Hiigara from the Taiidan, encountering a variety of pirates, mercenaries, traders, and rebels along the way.
sentence_2: In each of the game's levels, the player gathers resources, builds a fleet, and uses it to destroy enemy ships and accomplish mission objectives.

sentence_1: The player's fleet carries over between levels, and can travel in a fully three-dimensional space within each level rather than being limited to a two-dimensional plane.Homeworld was created over two years, and was the first game developed by Relic.
sentence_2: Studio co-founders Alex Garden and Luke Moloney served as the director and lead programmer for the game, respectively.

sentence_1: The initial concept for the game's story is credited to writer David J. Williams, while the script itself was written by Martin Cirulis and the background lore was written by author Arinn Dembo.
sentence_2: The music of the game was written by composer Paul Ruskay as the first title from his Studio X Labs, with the exception of Samuel Barber's 1936 Adagio for Strings, considered the defining theme of the game, and a licensed track from English rock band Yes, "Homeworld (The Ladder)".Homeworld is listed by review aggregator Metacritic as the highest rated computer game of 1999, and the fourth-highest on any platform for the year.

sentence_1: Critics praised the game's graphics, unique gameplay elements, and multiplayer system, though opinions were divided on the game's plot and high difficulty.
sentence_2: The game sold over 500,000 copies in its first 6 months, and received several awards and nominations for best strategy game of the year and best game of the year.

sentence_1: A release of the game's source code in 2003 sparked unofficial ports to macOS and Linux, and three more games in the Homeworld series have been produced: Homeworld: Cataclysm (2000), Homeworld 2 (2003), and Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak (2016).
sentence_2: Gearbox Software purchased the rights to the series from then-owners THQ in 2013, and released a remastered collection of Homeworld and Homeworld 2 in 2015 for Windows and macOS which was also highly regarded.Homeworld is a real-time strategy game set in space.

sentence_1: Gameplay, as in most real-time strategy titles, is focused on gathering resources, building military forces, and using them to destroy enemy forces and accomplish an objective.
sentence_2: The game includes both single-player and multiplayer modes; the single-player mode consists of one story-driven campaign, broken up into levels.

sentence_1: In each level, the player has an objective to accomplish before they can end the level, though the ultimate objective of the mission can change as the level's story unfolds.
sentence_2: Between each of the 16 levels is a hand-drawn, black-and-white cutscene with narrative voiceovers.The central ship of the player's fleet is the mothership, a large base which can construct other ships; unlike other spacecraft, in the single-player campaign the mothership is unable to move.Each level's playable area is a sphere, bisected by a circular plane.

sentence_1: Ships can be directed to move anywhere in that sphere, either singularly or in groups.
sentence_2: The game's camera can be set to follow any ship and view them from any angle, as well as display the ship's point of view.

sentence_1: The player may also view the "Sensors Manager", wherein they can view the entire game map along with all visible ships.
sentence_2: Ships can be grouped into formations, such as wedges or spheres, in order to provide tactical advantages during combat with enemy ships.

sentence_1: Non-specialized ships are equipped with weapons to fire upon enemy ships, which include ballistic guns, beam weapons, and missiles.
sentence_2: As a ship is damaged by weapons its health bar depletes, visual effects such as fire and smoke are added, and it can eventually explode.When all mission objectives are completed, the player is given the option to make a hyperspace jump to end the level.

sentence_1: This may be postponed in order to gather more resources or build more ships.
sentence_2: When the hyperspace jump is initiated, all fighters return to the mothership while larger ships line up next to it, and blue rectangles pass over the ships and teleport them to the next level.A century prior to the start of the game, the Kushan, humanoid inhabitants of the desert planet Kharak, discovered a spaceship buried in the sands, which holds a stone map marking Kharak and another planet across the galaxy labelled "Hiigara", meaning "home".

sentence_1: The discovery united the clans of Kharak, who knew they were not indigenous to Kharak and craved to solve the mystery of how they came to this hostile planet.After destroying the remnants of both alien fleets, the nascent Kushan fleet sets out for Hiigara, intent on reclaiming their ancient homeworld.
sentence_2: Their multi-stage journey across the galaxy takes them through asteroid fields, a giant nebula, a ship graveyard and several Taiidan outposts.

sentence_1: Along the way, they fight other descendants of their Hiigaran ancestors who have turned to piracy.
sentence_2: They also meet the Bentusi, a race of traders, who sell them advanced technology.

sentence_1: After discovering that the Bentusi have given aid to the exiles, the Taiidan attempt to destroy them, but are stopped by the Kushan fleet.As their journey continues, the Kushan fleet gives sanctuary to the Taiidan rebel Captain Elson.
sentence_2: With his help, they rally a rebellion to distract the Taiidan fleets.Relic Entertainment was founded in Vancouver, Canada, on June 1, 1997, and began work on Homeworld as their first title.Relic did not specifically set out to create a real-time strategy game; Garden and Relic were primarily focused on making a game with exciting large-scale space battles, and chose the genre in order to support that.

sentence_1: As a result, they did not try to make innovative gameplay changes in the real-time strategy genre, but instead worked on making implementing the genre in a fully 3D space to make the space battles they envisioned.The focus on the combat drove several other areas of focus for the development team: according to Garden, Relic spent considerable effort on making high-quality ship models, computer-controlled flight tactics, and maneuvers like immelmann turns because "everyone is going to zoom right in on the first battle, just to watch".The sound design, audio production, and music composition for the game was contracted to composer Paul Ruskay and Studio X Labs, which he founded in February 1999 after starting on Homeworld in October 1998.
sentence_2: The closing song of the game, "Homeworld (The Ladder)", was licensed from English rock band Yes.Homeworld was highly regarded by critics upon release; it is listed by review aggregator Metacritic as the highest rated computer game of 1999, and the fourth-highest on any platform for the year.The gameplay advances were also highly praised by critics: Lopez claimed that "Relic not only tackled space, but may have just changed strategy games forever.

sentence_1: "Homeworld's single-player plot received mixed reviews; Lopez claimed it would keep players "rapt with attention", Samuel summized it as a "superb story", and Levine said that it was "the first computer game to capture the grandeur and epic feel of the Star Wars movies".
sentence_2: The Eurogamer review, however, considered it only "(mostly) engaging", and Keefer said that "although the story line is fluid and intriguing", for each mission "the overall theme is the same: Kill the enemy", while Ryan criticized the length for such a "meager single-player game".Homeworld was released to strong sales and won multiple awards; Homeworld also received a "Silver" sales award from the Entertainment and Leisure Software Publishers Association (ELSPA), indicating sales of at least 100,000 copies in the United Kingdom.Homeworld won Best Strategy Game at the 1999 Game Critics Awards prior to release,Homeworld inspired a series of real-time strategy games in the same universe, beginning in September 2000 when Sierra Studios released a stand-alone expansion by Barking Dog Studios, Homeworld: Cataclysm.

sentence_1: Air Marshal Sir John Patrick Joseph McCauley, KBE, CB (18 March 1899 – 3 February 1989) was a senior commander in the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF).
sentence_2: He served as Chief of the Air Staff from 1954 to 1957.

sentence_1: A Duntroon graduate, McCauley spent four years in the Australian Military Forces before transferring to the RAAF in 1924.
sentence_2: He was Director of Training from 1936 to 1938, and commanded engineering and flying training schools for the first eighteen months of World War II.

sentence_1: Having been promoted to group captain in 1940, he was posted to Singapore in June 1941 to take charge of all RAAF units defending the area.
sentence_2: He earned praise for his efforts in attacking invading Japanese forces before the fall of Singapore, and for his dedication in evacuating his men.

sentence_1: After serving as Deputy Chief of the Air Staff in 1942–44, he was appointed to a senior operational role with the Royal Air Force's 2nd Tactical Air Force in Europe, where he saw out the rest of the war.Following the end of hostilities, McCauley again became Deputy Chief of the Air Staff.
sentence_2: In 1947 he was promoted to air vice marshal and appointed Chief of Staff at British Commonwealth Occupation Force Headquarters in Japan.

sentence_1: Returning to Australia in June 1949, he served as the last Air Officer Commanding (AOC) Eastern Area and the inaugural AOC Home Command (now Air Command).
sentence_2: Raised to air marshal, he took up the position of Chief of the Air Staff in January 1954, and was knighted a year later.

sentence_1: During his tenure in the RAAF's senior role, McCauley focused on potential deployments to Southeast Asia—particularly Vietnam—and threats from the north, commencing redevelopment of RAAF Base Darwin and recommending purchase of a light supersonic bomber to replace the Air Force's English Electric Canberra.
sentence_2: After retiring from military life in March 1957, he chaired various community and welfare organisations, serving as Federal President of the Air Force Association for ten years.

sentence_1: He died in Sydney in 1989, aged 89.Born in Sydney on 18 March 1899, McCauley went to school at St Joseph's College, Hunters Hill, before entering the Royal Military College, Duntroon, in 1916.
sentence_2: He graduated as a lieutenant in 1919, and spent the next four years in staff positions with the Permanent Military Forces, including a posting to Britain.Promoted to squadron leader, McCauley was posted a third time to Britain in 1933, graduating from RAF Staff College, Andover, and qualifying as a flight instructor at Central Flying School, Wittering.

sentence_1: The following year he was attached to the Air Ministry in London.McCauley's seniority and instructional experience kept him in Australia on training assignments for the first eighteen months of World War II.
sentence_2: From March to October 1940, he served as the inaugural commander of No.

sentence_1: 1 Engineering School at Ascot Vale, Victoria.During the Malayan Campaign in 1941–42, McCauley was in charge of RAAF units under Britain's Far East Air Force (FEAF).
sentence_2: By Christmas, as the Allies retreated from Malaya, Sembawang was "the busiest airfield on Singapore island", with two Dutch Glenn Martin bomber squadrons in addition to the remnants of the Hudson units, along with Nos.

sentence_1: 21 and 453 Squadrons (merged due to losses as No.
sentence_2: 21/453 Squadron), operating obsolescent Brewster Buffalos.After his return to Australia late in February 1942, McCauley briefly served as Senior Air Staff Officer at North-Western Area Headquarters in Darwin, Northern Territory.

sentence_1: He took up the position of Deputy Chief of the Air Staff (DCAS) in May, and was appointed a Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in the 1943 King's Birthday Honours, promulgated on 2 June.Completing his term as DCAS, McCauley was posted to the European theatre in November 1944, serving for the remainder of the war as Air Commodore (Operations), 2nd Tactical Air Force RAF (2nd TAF).Among a small coterie of wartime RAAF commanders earmarked for further senior roles, McCauley retained his rank of air commodore following the cessation of hostilities.
sentence_2: Upon his return to Australia, McCauley was made Air Officer Commanding Eastern Area.

sentence_1: During the Malayan Emergency, he formed RAAF aircraft assigned for deployment into No.
sentence_2: 90 (Composite) Wing, as directed by Chief of the Air Staff Air Marshal George Jones, to ensure that they would operate with a degree of autonomy rather than be dispersed throughout other Allied groups.

sentence_1: He was appointed a Companion of the Order of the Bath (CB) in the 1951 Birthday Honours.In January 1952, Air Marshal Jones was succeeded by Air Marshal Sir Donald Hardman of the Royal Air Force.
sentence_2: The decision by Prime Minister Robert Menzies to appoint a British officer as CAS caused controversy in Australia, compounded by his stated reason that there was "no RAAF officer of sufficient age, or operational experience, to take the post of Chief of the Air Staff", which ignored the wartime records of figures like McCauley.

sentence_1: Hardman changed the structure of the Air Force from one based on geographical area to one based on function, hence McCauley's Eastern Area Command evolved into Home Command (now Air Command) in 1953.McCauley was raised to Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire (KBE) in the 1955 New Year Honours.
sentence_2: McCauley's tenure as CAS saw the beginning of a trend for the RAAF to equip with US aircraft types in preference to British types, with recommendations being put forward for the F-104 Starfighter (though in the event the French Dassault Mirage III was purchased) and C-130 Hercules.

sentence_1: This stemmed partly from his inspection of Allied air force units during the Korean War, when he observed that those employing American hardware were far better served with spare parts and replacement aircraft than those with British equipment.McCauley instigated the redevelopment of RAAF Base Darwin in the Northern Territory as the first stage of a forward defence strategy.
sentence_2: He aimed to make Darwin the "main Australian base for war" and a launching point for deployments to Southeast Asia, rather than simply a transit station.

sentence_1: Over the next ten years, No.
sentence_2: 5 Airfield Construction Squadron transformed the base's runways, buildings and other infrastructure into a modern facility capable of handling major operations.

sentence_1: This concept was taken another step by McCauley's successor as CAS, Air Marshal Scherger, who conceived a series of front-line "bare bases" across Northern Australia, beginning with plans for RAAF Base Tindal in 1959.After his retirement from the RAAF on 18 March 1957, In 1970, he played a leading role in organising the Australian Services Council (later the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council) to co-ordinate lobbying efforts for various veterans' groups, and became its first chairman.McCauley died in Sydney's St Vincent's Hospital on 3 February 1989, following a stroke.
sentence_2: Aged 89, he was survived by his three children; his wife had died two years earlier.

sentence_1: Sonic: After the Sequel is a 2013 platform video game created by Brazilian student Felipe Daneluz (LakeFeperd).
sentence_2: It is an unofficial game based on the Sonic the Hedgehog series and set between the official games Sonic the Hedgehog 2 and Sonic the Hedgehog 3.

sentence_1: Daneluz's second Sonic game, it follows Sonic: Before the Sequel, which set between the original Sonic the Hedgehog and Sonic the Hedgehog 2.
sentence_2: Like its predecessor, After the Sequel stars Sonic the Hedgehog and his sidekick Tails in a quest to retrieve the Chaos Emeralds from Doctor Eggman.After the Sequel was inspired by Sonic Heroes and other games both inside and outside the Sonic series, and it was developed with Sonic Worlds, an engine based in Multimedia Fusion 2 that reduces the amount of computer programming involved in game creation.

sentence_1: It was released as a free download for Microsoft Windows personal computers on June 15, 2013.
sentence_2: The game was very well received by video game journalists, who lauded its preservation of retro Sonic gameplay and its eclectic, 1990s-style soundtrack.

sentence_1: The trilogy of Before the Sequel, After the Sequel, and their successor Sonic Chrono Adventure performed unusually well for fangames, having been downloaded 120,000 times by March 2014.After the Sequel is a 2D platformer in the style of the Sonic games for the Sega Genesis.The player collects rings in zones and boss fights as a form of health: upon being hit by an enemy or harmful obstacle, the player's rings will scatter and can be recollected.
sentence_2: Being hit while carrying no rings, being crushed by an obstacle, or falling into a bottomless pit causes the player to lose a life; running out of lives results in a game over screen, after which the player must restart the zone from act one.

sentence_1: Conversely, collecting 100 rings gets the player an extra life, and completing an act with 50 takes the player to a special stage, where they can collect rings for extra lives.
sentence_2: The game also features power-ups throughout its zones,At the end of Sonic the Hedgehog 2, Sonic and Tails fly over the ocean in Tails' biplane, the Tornado, after defeating Doctor Eggman.

sentence_1: After the Sequel depicts Sonic and Tails noticing a forested island and deciding to make a landing and explore.
sentence_2: After completing the first zone, Sonic finds a robot resembling Tails—a trap sprung by Eggman.

sentence_1: The robot ensnares Sonic in a forcefield while Eggman steals Sonic's Chaos Emeralds.
sentence_2: Sonic escapes and sets out with Tails to recover the Emeralds.The two travel through more zones and fight Eggman at the end of each one.

sentence_1: They follow Eggman to a forest, where he leads a massive logging operation.
sentence_2: Together with Mighty the Armadillo, they destroy his machinery and stop the operation.

sentence_1: They continue through the forest and find ghosts that frighten Tails.
sentence_2: Destroying one of Eggman's robots lets Sonic see its internal architecture, including a screen that shows Eggman's plans to create an empire and drop a floating island into the sea.In Parhelion Peak, the game's snow zone, Sonic and Tails notice a feather float down from the sky.

sentence_1: They board another of Eggman's airships and complete another zone, whereupon they find another feather.
sentence_2: They trace the feathers to Eggman's bird-like robot, which is guarding the Emeralds.

sentence_1: Sonic retrieves the Emeralds and uses them to become Super Sonic.
sentence_2: He fights the robot as the game's final boss.

sentence_1: After its defeat, Sonic and Tails fly aboard the Tornado once more—the segue into the events of Sonic the Hedgehog 3.After the Sequel was created by Felipe Daneluz (known on the Internet as "LakeFeperd"), a student from São Paulo, Brazil.
sentence_2: Unlike many longtime Sonic fans, Daneluz remained supportive of the series through its "dark age" in the mid to late 2000s and enjoyed games such as Sonic Riders.After the Sequel's zones were inspired largely by those of Sonic Heroes.The music composition and recording were handled by underground musicians Falk Au Yeong, Funk Fiction, Andy Tunstall,In August 2017, Daneluz re-released the game as Sonic: After the Sequel DX.

sentence_1: This version features improved physics, the addition of the drop dash from Sonic Mania, and a new final boss.After the Sequel has received positive coverage for its revitalization of retro Sonic gameplay.
sentence_2: Tony Ponce of Destructoid summarized it as "quite the fun little gem that keeps the Genesis-era Sonic spirit alive".

sentence_1: He contrasted the retro, fan-made After the Sequel with Sega's efforts to create high-quality 3D titles, lamenting that, fifteen years after the release of Sonic Adventure, Sega was "only now starting to get the hang of the third dimension.
sentence_2: "The game's music has been particularly well received.

sentence_1: Ponce called it "the best music ever" and "simply indescribable", opining that it raised an already high-quality product "to god tier".The game is available as a free download for Windows personal computers.
sentence_2: As of March 2014, the trilogy had been downloaded 120,000 times—an unusually high number for fangames—as compared to the 640,000 copies of the official game Sonic Lost World (also released in 2013) sold on the Wii U by the same time.

sentence_1: George Gibson Macaulay (7 December 1897 – 13 December 1940) was a professional English cricketer who played first-class cricket for Yorkshire County Cricket Club between 1920 and 1935.
sentence_2: He played in eight Test matches for England from 1923 to 1933, achieving the rare feat of taking a wicket with his first ball in Test cricket.

sentence_1: One of the five Wisden Cricketers of the Year in 1924,  he took 1,838 first-class wickets at an average of 17.64 including four hat-tricks.A leading member of the Yorkshire team which achieved a high level of success in the time he played, Macaulay was a volatile character who played aggressively.
sentence_2: He left a job at a bank to become a professional cricketer, making his first-class debut aged 23 as a fast bowler.

sentence_1: Meeting limited success, he altered style to deliver off spin in addition to his pace bowling.
sentence_2: This proved so effective that he was chosen to play for England in Test matches.

sentence_1: However, his perceived poor attitude towards the game, and an unsuccessful match in the 1926 Ashes probably prevented him playing more Tests.
sentence_2: His form slumped following injuries in the late 1920s, but a recovery in the early 1930s led to a recall by England, although he broke down in his second match back.

sentence_1: Another injury in 1934 made cricket difficult for him and his first-class career ended in 1935, although he continued playing club cricket until the Second World War.
sentence_2: A pilot officer in the Royal Air Force, he died of pneumonia on active service in the Second World War.Macaulay was born in Thirsk on 7 December 1897.

sentence_1: His father was a well-known local cricketer, as were his uncles.In 1920, Yorkshire needed to strengthen its bowling attack.
sentence_2: Of the team's previously successful bowlers, Major Booth had been killed in the war, Alonzo Drake had died soon afterwards from illness, and George Hirst was past his best.

sentence_1: Although Wilfred Rhodes was able to ease the shortfall by resuming his career as a frontline spin bowler, Yorkshire needed new bowlers, particularly pacemen.Bowling a mixture of medium pace and his new style of off spin, This included a maiden first-class century against Nottinghamshire.
sentence_2: His innings of 125 not out took Yorkshire from 211 for seven wickets when he came in to bat (228 for eight soon after) to a total of 438 for nine declared, a lead of 264; Yorkshire went on to a comfortable win.Macaulay improved his bowling record in 1922, taking more wickets at a lower average (133 wickets at an average of 14.67), He continued to pick up wickets, but his most significant performance came in June.

sentence_1: In front of Marylebone Cricket Club (MCC) members at Lord's, he took five for 31 as Middlesex were bowled out for 138.
sentence_2: Those watching were impressed and he was selected for the Players against the Gentlemen at the same ground in July.

sentence_1: He took three for 97 out of a total of 430 in one of the most important matches of the season.Macaulay played eight first-class matches in South Africa in 1922–23, taking 29 wickets at an average of 16.37.With his health improved by the tour, Wisden reported that Macaulay was in excellent form for the whole of the 1923 season.In 1924, Macaulay further increased his total of wickets to 190 and lowered his bowling average to 13.23, placing him first in the national averages.Since 1923, Macaulay had run a cricket outfitters in Leeds and Wakefield with his Yorkshire team-mate Herbert Sutcliffe, borrowing £250 from his mother to help establish the business.
sentence_2: During the winter of 1924–25, the shop became a limited company and Macaulay one of its directors.Macaulay's most successful season in terms of wickets was 1925, despite a very dry summer which produced a succession of good batting pitches.

sentence_1: He took 211 wickets at an average of 15.48, coming top of the Yorkshire averages.Yorkshire's reign as County Champions ended in 1926, the first season since 1921 when Yorkshire did not win the Championship.Macaulay was selected for the third Test against Australia at Headingley, possibly because Arthur Carr, the England captain, expected the pitch to favour spinners.
sentence_2: The Australians were concerned that Macaulay represented a threat to their batting, but the match did not work out in Macaulay's favour as a bowler; having been dropped at the start of play, Charlie Macartney played what Wisden called one of the best innings of his career and vigorously attacked the England bowling, achieving the rare feat of scoring a century before the lunch interval.

sentence_1: The Australian batsman had asked his captain if he could attack Macaulay in particular, and the Yorkshire bowler suffered as Macartney quickly dominated him.
sentence_2: Macaulay eventually had Macartney caught after hitting a short ball in the air, but it was Macaulay's only success in the innings.

sentence_1: Macaulay conceded 123 runs in 32 overs as Australia scored 494.Over the next four seasons, Yorkshire failed to win the Championship, although they never finished lower than fourth in the table.In 1927, Macaulay took 130 wickets at an average of 18.26.From the 1931 season, Yorkshire once again dominated the County Championship, winning three consecutive trophies.The 1933 season signalled a return to form for Macaulay.
sentence_2: Wisden judged that he "recovered fully his length, spin and command over variations in pace".Macaulay's final two seasons were affected by injury, as he was increasingly bothered by rheumatism.Macaulay ended his career with 1,837 first-class wickets at an average of 17.65.

sentence_1: In eight Test matches, he took 24 of those wickets at an average of 27.58.
sentence_2: In addition, he scored 6,055 runs at an average of 18.07 and held 373 catches.Following his retirement, Macaulay initially attempted to market a patented rheumatic medicine, but the business quickly failed.

sentence_1: He then established an athletic outfitting shop in Leeds.
sentence_2: This business also was unsuccessful;Macaulay played league cricket in Wales and Lancashire until the Second World War.When the Second World War began, Macaulay joined the Royal Air Force (RAF) Volunteer Reserve in 1940 as a Pilot Officer, and was stationed at Church Fenton, close to Barkston Ash where he lived with his wife Edith.

sentence_1: Later in the year, he was stationed in the Shetland Islands, where he was bothered by the cold.As a batsman, Macaulay was reasonably good and possibly better than his statistics would suggest.
sentence_2: He was capable of batting well in a crisis but may have been prevented from honing his batting skills by the Yorkshire leadership who wished him to focus on bowling.As a bowler, Macaulay fulfilled two roles.

sentence_1: At the start of an innings, when the ball was new and hard, he opened the bowling with medium-fast deliveries that swung away from right-handed batsmen.
sentence_2: In this style, he was very accurate and bowled a variety of deliveries to unsettle his opponents.

sentence_1: Cricket writer R. C. Robertson-Glasgow considered him to be better than any similar bowler in the 1920s except Maurice Tate, the leading medium paced bowler in England.Macaulay's bowling action was relaxed and effortless, being admired by his contemporaries.Macaulay displayed a temper when matters went against him.
sentence_2: Media related to George Macaulay at Wikimedia Commons

sentence_1: Beth Hamedrash Hagodol (Hebrew: .mw-parser-output .script-hebrew,.mw-parser-output .script-Hebr{font-size:1.15em;font-family:"Ezra SIL","Ezra SIL SR","Keter Aram Tsova","Taamey Ashkenaz","Taamey David CLM","Taamey Frank CLM","Frank Ruehl CLM","Keter YG","Shofar","David CLM","Hadasim CLM","Simple CLM","Nachlieli","SBL BibLit","SBL Hebrew",Cardo,Alef,"Noto Serif Hebrew","Noto Sans Hebrew","David Libre",David,"Times New Roman",Gisha,Arial,FreeSerif,FreeSans}בֵּית הַמִּדְרָש הַגָּדוֹל, "Great Study House") is an Orthodox Jewish congregation that for over 120 years was located in a historic building at 60–64 Norfolk Street between Grand and Broome Streets in the Lower East Side neighborhood of Manhattan, New York City.
sentence_2: It was the first Eastern European congregation founded in New York City and the oldest Russian Jewish Orthodox congregation in the United States.Founded in 1852 by Rabbi Abraham Ash as Beth Hamedrash, the congregation split in 1859, with the rabbi and most of the members renaming their congregation Beth Hamedrash Hagodol.

sentence_1: The congregation's president and a small number of the members eventually formed the nucleus of Kahal Adath Jeshurun, also known as the Eldridge Street Synagogue.The congregation's building, a Gothic Revival structure built in 1850 as the Norfolk Street Baptist Church and purchased in 1885, was one of the largest synagogues on the Lower East Side.The synagogue was closed in 2007.
sentence_2: The congregation, reduced to around 20 regularly attending members, was sharing facilities with a congregation on Henry Street.The abandoned synagogue was "largely destroyed" by a "suspicious" three-alarm fire on May 14, 2017.Beth Hamedrash Hagodol was founded by Eastern European Jews in 1852 as Beth Hamedrash (literally "House of Study", but used colloquially in Yiddish as the term for a synagogue).

sentence_1: The founding rabbi, Abraham Joseph Ash, was born in Siemiatycze (then in Congress Poland) in 1813 He soon organized a minyan (prayer quorum) of like-minded Polish Jews,The congregation moved frequently in its early years: in 1852 it was located at 83 Bayard Street, then at Elm and Canal, and from 1853 to 1856 in a hall at Pearl between ChathamSynagogue dues were collected by the shamash (the equivalent of a sexton or beadle), who augmented his salary by working as a glazier and running a small food concession stand in the vestibule.
sentence_2: There mourners who came to recite kaddish could purchase a piece of sponge cake and small glass of brandy for ten cents (today $2.80).Beth Hamedrash was the prototypical American synagogue for early immigrant Eastern European Jews, who began entering the United States in large numbers only in the 1870s.

sentence_1: They found the synagogues of the German Jewish immigrants who preceded them to be unfamiliar, both religiously and culturally.
sentence_2: Russian Jews in particular had been more excluded from Russian society than were German Jews from German society, for both linguistic and social reasons.

sentence_1: Unlike German Jews, the Jews who founded Beth Hamedrash viewed both religion and the synagogue as central to their lives.
sentence_2: They attempted to re-create in Beth Hamedrash the kind of synagogue they had belonged to in Europe.In 1859, disagreement broke out between Ash and the synagogue's parnas (president) Joshua Rothstein a large majority of members left with Ash to form Beth Hamedrash Hagodol ("Great House of Study"), adding the word "Hagodol" ("Great") to the original name.The followers of Rothstein stayed at the Allen Street location and retained the name "Beth Hamedrash" until the mid-1880s.

sentence_1: With membership and financial resources both severely reduced, they were forced to merge with Congregation Holche Josher Wizaner; the combined congregation adopted the name "Kahal Adath Jeshurun", and built the Eldridge Street Synagogue.According to Eisenstein, Beth Hamedrash Hagodol provided an atmosphere that was "socially religious", in which Jews "combineThe congregation initially moved to the top floor of a building at the corner of Grand and Forsyth Streets, and in 1865 moved again, to a former courthouse on Clinton Street.
sentence_2: In 1872, the congregation built a synagogue at Ludlow and Hester Streets.

sentence_1: There the congregation's younger members gained greater control and introduced some minor innovations; for example, changing the title of parnas to president, and in 1877 hiring a professional cantor—Judah Oberman—for $500 (today $11,800) per year, to bring greater formality and decorum to the servicesAsh had only served as Beth Hamedrash Hagodol's rabbi intermittently during this time; and agreed to select the Malbim (Meïr Leibush ben Jehiel Michel Weiser) for the role.
sentence_2: (or $300—today $8,000—per year).

sentence_1: The following year the congregation hired a new cantor, Simhe Samuelson, for $1,000 (today $27,000) a year, over three times Ash's salary.The congregation's building at 60-64 Norfolk Street, between Grand Street and Broome Street on the Lower East Side, had originally been the Norfolk Street Baptist Church.
sentence_2: Founded in 1841 when the Stanton Street Baptist Church congregation split, the members had first worshiped in an existing church building at Norfolk and Broome.

sentence_1: In 1848 they officially incorporated and began construction of a new building, which was dedicated in January 1850.Largely unchanged, the structure was designed in the Gothic Revival style by an unknown architect, with masonry-bearing walls with timber framing at the roof and floors, and brownstone foundation walls and exterior door and window trim.
sentence_2: The front facade (west, on Norfolk Street) is "stuccoed and scored to simulate smooth-faced ashlar", though the other elevations are faced in brick.

sentence_1: Window tracery was all in wood.
sentence_2: Much of the original work remains on the side elevations.Even as the building was under construction, the ethnic makeup of the church's neighborhood was rapidly changing; native-born Baptists were displaced by Irish and German immigrants.

sentence_1: As members moved uptown, the congregation decided to follow and sold their building in 1860 to Alanson T. Biggs, a successful local merchant.
sentence_2: The departing Baptist congregation founded the Fifth Avenue Baptist church, then founded the Park Avenue Church, and finally built the Riverside Church.Biggs converted the church to one for Methodists,Founded in 1866, the Church Extension and Missionary Society's mission was "... to promote Churches, Missions, and Sunday-schools in the City of New York.

sentence_1: "In 1885 Beth Hamedrash Hagodol purchased the building for $45,000 (today $1.3 million), and made alterations and repairs at a cost of $10,000 (today $280,000), but made no external modifications by the re-opening.
sentence_2: Alterations to the interior were generally made to adapt it to synagogue use.

sentence_1: These included the additions of an Ark to hold the Torah scrolls (replacing the original pulpit), an "eternal light" in front of the ark, and a bimah (a central elevated platform where the Torah scrolls are read).
sentence_2: At some time a women's gallery was added round three sides of the nave.In addition to attracting new and wealthy members, the congregation intended the substantial building to garner prestige and respectability for the relatively new immigrant Jews from Eastern Europe, and to show that Jews on the Lower East Side could be just as "civilized" as the reform-minded Jews of uptown Manhattan.

sentence_1: They also hired increasingly expensive cantors until, in 1886, Kahal Adath Jeshurun hired P. Minkowsy for the "then-staggering sum of five thousand dollars per annum" (today $139,000).
sentence_2: (or Michalovsky).Though the building had undergone previous alterations—for example, the Church Extension and Missionary Society had "removed deteriorated parapets from the towers" in 1880—it did not undergo significant renovations until the early 1890s.

sentence_1: That year the rose window on the front of the building was removed, "possibly because it had Christian motifs", and replaced with a large arched window, still in keeping with the Gothic style.
sentence_2: The work was undertaken by the architectural firm of (Ernest) Schneider & (Henry) Herter, German immigrants who had worked on a number of other synagogues, including the Park East Synagogue.

sentence_1: In 1893 they fixed "serious structural problems", the consequence of neglected maintenance.
sentence_2: The work included "stabilizTwo Stars of David were added to the center of the facade.

sentence_1: One is seen in the old photograph (above left), over a palmette ornament at the top of the window arch.
sentence_2: The other, mounted above the top of the gable, remains visible in the modern photograph (top).

sentence_1: The unusual cupola-like structure on legs seen above the gable in the old photograph, now gone, was also added by the synagogue, as was the square structure on which it sat.Ash died in 1887, and the United Hebrew Orthodox Congregations (now called The Association of American Orthodox Hebrew Congregations) began a search for a successor, to serve as rabbi of Beth Hamedrash Hagodol and as Chief Rabbi of New York City.
sentence_2: This search was opposed by Rabbi Henry Pereira Mendes, of Congregation Shearith Israel.

sentence_1: Mendes felt that the money and energy would be better spent on supporting the Jewish Theological Seminary of America (JTSA), which he had co-founded with Sabato Morais in 1886.
sentence_2: In his view, training American-born rabbis at the Seminary would be a much more effective means of fighting the growing strength of American Reform Judaism: these native English-speaking rabbis would appeal to the younger generation far more than imported, Yiddish-speaking ones.The Association of American Orthodox Hebrew Congregations rejected Morais's position, and offered the role to a number of "leading East European Orthodox rabbis", all of whom turned it down.

sentence_1: They eventually narrowed the field to two candidates, Zvi Rabinovitch and Jacob Joseph.Born in Kroz, Lithuania, Joseph had studied in the Volozhin yeshiva under Naftali Zvi Yehuda Berlin; he was known there as Rav Yaakov Charif ("Rabbi Jacob Sharp") because of his sharp mind.
sentence_2: He was one of the main disciples of Yisroel Salanter, and in 1883 had been appointed the maggid (preacher) of Vilna.

sentence_1: Beth Hamedrash Hagodol, the Eldridge Street Synagogue, and 13 other Lower East Side synagogues had raised $2,500 (today $70,000) towards the creation of a European style kehilla to oversee New York's Orthodox community, and had imported Joseph in an attempt to achieve that (ultimately unfulfilled) goal.Joseph arrived in New York on July 7, 1888, and later that month preached his inaugural Sabbath sermon at Beth Hamedrash Hagodol.In October 1888, Joseph made his first significant statement as Chief Rabbi.
sentence_2: He issued new regulations for New York's Jewish poultry business, in an attempt to bring it into accordance with Jewish law.

sentence_1: The funds for supporting the agency supervising adherence to these regulations were to be raised through an increase in the price of meat and chicken.
sentence_2: The affected vendors and consumers, however, refused to pay this levy.Joseph was also unable to stop those who came to hear him speak from desecrating the Sabbath, and his Yiddish sermons had no impact on the younger generation.

sentence_1: In addition, he had to contend with a number of obstacles: he had no administrative experience or training, local Orthodox rabbis (particularly Joshua Seigel) and Jews outside his congregation did not accept his authority, and non-Orthodox Jews and groups criticized him.In the late 19th century, other synagogues in New York City often served a particular constituency, typically Jews from a single town in Russia, Poland, or Romania.
sentence_2: Beth Hamedrash Hagodol prided itself in welcoming and assisting all Jews, regardless of origins.

sentence_1: By the turn of the 20th century, Beth Hamedrash Hagodol was distributing approximately $800 (today $24,000) a year to the poor for Passover supplies, compared to a total synagogue income of around $5,000 (today $151,000).
sentence_2: This was on top of its average $15 (today $500) weekly contributions to the poor, and those of individual congregational members of around $2,000 (today $60,000) per annum.

sentence_1: By 1901, annual revenues were around $6,000 (today $181,000), and the congregation had 150 members.During Joseph's tenure, Beth Hamedrash Hagodol helped found the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America (the "Orthodox Union").
sentence_2: In the spring of 1898, 50 lay officials from a number of Orthodox New York synagogues—including Congregation Ohab Zedek, the Eldridge Street Synagogue, Congregation Shearith Israel and Beth Hamedrash Hagodol—convened to create the organization.Joseph served as the synagogue's rabbi from his arrival in the United States in 1888 until his death in 1902 at age 62.

sentence_1: After his death, Beth Hamedrash Hagodol secured the right to bury him in its cemetery by promising his widow $1,500 (today $43,000) and a monthly $15 stipend; in turn, individuals offered the congregation large sums—$5,000 (today $145,000) in one case—for the right to be buried near him.Joseph was succeeded by Rabbi Shalom Elchanan Jaffe, a founder of the Union of Orthodox Rabbis and a strong supporter of the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary.
sentence_2: Jaffe, who was born near Vilna, had, like Joseph, studied at the Volozhin yeshiva, and had received his rabbinic ordination from Naftali Zvi Yehuda Berlin and Yitzchak Elchanan Spektor.

sentence_1: The author of several books of religious commentary, Jaffe was an influential rabbi on the Lower East Side, in part because of his authority over kosher supervision of New York's butcher stores and slaughterhouses.Harry Fischel was the congregation's Vice President until 1902; there he first met and eventually attended the Bar Mitzvah of his future son-in-law, Herbert S. Goldstein.
sentence_2: founded the Institutional Synagogue in Harlem.

sentence_1: He is the only person to have been president of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, the Rabbinical Council of America (first presidium), and the Synagogue Council of America.Beth Hamedrash Hagodol had 175 member families by 1908, and the synagogue's annual revenues were $10,000 (today $270,000).Dr.
sentence_2: Benjamin Fleischer, a noted orator, was elected rabbi of Beth Hamedrash Hagodol in September 1924.

sentence_1: In May 1939, he and two other rabbis (and a fourth rabbi as secretary) formed the first permanent beth din (court of Jewish law) in the U.S.In the early-to-mid-20th century the congregation's financial footing was still not sound; though the Norfolk Street building had been purchased in 1885 for $45,000 (and $10,000 in alterations and repairs), in 1921 it still owed $40,000 (today $560,000) on the mortgage.
sentence_2: At the end of December 1946, then-president Abraham Greenwald stated that unless $35,000 (today $450,000) were immediately raised for the repair of the building, it would have to be demolished.Ephraim Oshry, noted Torah scholar and religious leader in the Kovno Ghetto, and one of the few European Jewish legal decisors to survive The Holocaust, became the synagogue's rabbi in 1952, a post he retained for over 50 years.The congregation's building was again threatened with demolition in 1967, but Oshry, possibly the first Lower East Side rabbi to recognize the value of landmark designation, was successful in having it designated a New York City landmark, thus saving it.In 1974, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission applied to have the building added to the National Register of Historic Places, and considered significant at the state level; on the application the building's condition was described as "excellent".

sentence_1: but in subsequent years deteriorated and suffered damage.In the summer of 1997, a storm blew out the main two-storyThe congregation raised $40,000 in 2000 for emergency repairs, and was awarded a $230,000 grant by the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation for restoration work, including roof repair, but had not been able to raise the matching funds required to receive the grant.
sentence_2: On December 6, 2001, a fire and subsequent fire-fighting efforts severely damaged the roof, ceiling, mural paintings and decorative plasterwork.The National Trust for Historic Preservation designated the building an endangered historic site in 2003, It still retained a number of significant architectural features, including "the ornate ark and pulpit, central bimah (reader's platform) with etched glass lamps, cantilevered balconies, Gothic vaulted ceiling, and colorful wall paintings"; the lighting included "converted gas fixtures".By 2006, $1 million of an estimated required $3.5 million had been raised for repairs to the structure.Reportedly, the Lower East Side Conservancy was trying to raise an estimate $4.5 million for repairs, with the intent of turning the building into an educational center.

sentence_1: It was granted $215,000 by the United States Department of Education and was promised an equal amount by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.
sentence_2: Several years earlier the Conservancy had also been promised a total of $980,000 from New York State, the City Council, Mayor Bloomberg, and the Manhattan Borough President's office, but had yet to receive most of the city funds.

sentence_1: The group was also trying to raise $400,000 from private donors for the first phase of the renovation, which would secure the structure and roof.By the end of 2012 at least a million dollars in grants for repairs to the building had gone unused and were rescinded.On May 14, 2017, shortly after 7 p.m., a three-alarm fire broke out in the unused synagogue after what an eyewitness called a "big explosion".
sentence_2: The fire was brought under control at around midnight by approximately 150 firefighters – but not before it "largely destroyed" the structure.

sentence_1: Although still under investigation as of Monday May 15, the fire was said to seem "suspicious" due to surveillance video that showed three young people running from the area just before the fire broke out.
sentence_2: The fire brought down the ceiling and walls of the synagogue, creating a 15-foot (4.6 m) pile of rubble.In the aftermath of the fire, the synagogue took steps for the possible demolition of the building.

sentence_1: The city's Department of Buildings had determined that the remains of the building was unstable, but would not approve an emergency demolition, so a board member filed an application with the New York City Landmark Preservation Commission (LPC) for a general demolition permit, which did not specify how much of the structure was planned to be razed; that will depend on a determination of "structural findings".
sentence_2: The synagogue also provided materials to Community Board 3, with a request that their application be heard by an advisory panel.

sentence_1: The Priestley Riots (also known as the Birmingham Riots of 1791) took place from 14 July to 17 July 1791 in Birmingham, England; the rioters' main targets were religious dissenters, most notably the politically and theologically controversial Joseph Priestley.
sentence_2: Both local and national issues stirred the passions of the rioters, from disagreements over public library book purchases, to controversies over Dissenters' attempts to gain full civil rights and their support of the French Revolution.The riots started with an attack on the Royal Hotel, Birmingham—the site of a banquet organised in sympathy with the French Revolution.

sentence_1: Then, beginning with Priestley's church and home, the rioters attacked or burned four Dissenting chapels, twenty-seven houses, and several businesses.
sentence_2: Many of them became intoxicated by liquor that they found while looting, or with which they were bribed to stop burning homes.

sentence_1: A small core could not be bribed, however, and remained sober.
sentence_2: The rioters burned not only the homes and chapels of Dissenters, but also the homes of people they associated with Dissenters, such as members of the scientific Lunar Society.While the riots were not initiated by Prime Minister William Pitt's administration, the national government was slow to respond to the Dissenters' pleas for help.

sentence_1: Local Birmingham officials seem to have been involved in the planning of the riots, and they were later reluctant to prosecute any ringleaders.
sentence_2: Industrialist James Watt wrote that the riots "divided  Those who had been attacked gradually left, leaving Birmingham a more conservative city than it had been throughout the eighteenth century.Over the course of the eighteenth century, Birmingham became notorious for its riots, which were sparked by a number of causes.

sentence_1: In 1714 and 1715, the townspeople, as part of a "Church-and-King" mob, attacked Dissenters (Protestants who did not adhere to the Church of England or follow its practices) in the Sacheverell riots during the London trial of Henry Sacheverell, and in 1751 and 1759 Quakers and Methodists were assaulted.
sentence_2: During the anti-Catholic Gordon Riots in 1780, large crowds assembled in Birmingham.

sentence_1: In 1766, 1782, 1795, and 1800 mobs protested about high food prices.Up until the late 1780s, religious divisions did not affect Birmingham's elite.
sentence_2: Dissenter and Anglican lived side by side harmoniously: they were on the same town promotional committees; they pursued joint scientific interests in the Lunar Society; and they worked together in local government.

sentence_1: They stood united against what they viewed as the threat posed by unruly plebeians.
sentence_2: After the riots, however, scientist and clergyman Joseph Priestley argued in his An Appeal to the Public on the Subject of the Birmingham Riots (1791) that this cooperation had not in fact been as amicable as generally believed.

sentence_1: Priestley revealed that disputes over the local library, Sunday Schools, and church attendance had divided Dissenters from Anglicans.
sentence_2: In his Narrative of the Riots in Birmingham (1816), stationer and Birmingham historian William Hutton agreed, arguing that five events stoked the fires of religious friction: disagreements over inclusion of Priestley's books in the local public library; concerns over Dissenters' attempts to repeal the Test and Corporation Acts; religious controversy (particularly involving Priestley); an "inflammatory hand-bill"; and a dinner celebrating the outbreak of the French Revolution.Once Birmingham Dissenters started to agitate for the repeal of the Test and Corporation Acts, which restricted Dissenters' civil rights (preventing them, for instance, from attending the Universities of Oxford or Cambridge, or from holding public office), the semblance of unity among the town's elite disappeared.

sentence_1: Unitarians such as Priestley were at the forefront of the repeal campaign, and orthodox Anglicans grew nervous and angry.
sentence_2: After 1787, the emergence of Dissenting groups formed for the sole purpose of overturning these laws began to divide the community; however, the repeal efforts failed in 1787, 1789 and 1790.In addition to these religious and political differences, both the lower-class rioters and their upper-class Anglican leaders had economic complaints against the middle-class Dissenters.

sentence_1: They envied the ever-increasing prosperity of these industrialists as well as the power that came with that economic success.
sentence_2: Priestley himself had written a pamphlet, An Account of a Society for Encouraging the Industrious Poor (1787), on how best to extract the most work for the smallest amount of money from the poor.

sentence_1: Its emphasis on debt collection did not endear him to the poverty-stricken.The British public debate over the French Revolution, or the Revolution Controversy, lasted from 1789 through 1795.After the publication of statesman and philosopher Edmund Burke's Reflections on the Revolution in France (1790), in which he surprisingly broke ranks with his liberal Whig colleagues to support the French aristocracy, a pamphlet war discussing the Revolution began in earnest.
sentence_2: Because Burke had supported the American colonists in their rebellion against England, his views sent a shockwave through the country.

sentence_1: However, by December 1795, after the Reign of Terror and war with France, there were few who still supported the French cause or believed that reform would extend to Britain, and those suspected of remaining radicals became the subject of official and popular suspicion.The events which precipitated the Priestley Riots came less than a month after the attempted flight and arrest of the French Royal family, and at a point when much of the early promise of the Revolution had already dissipated.
